questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is seen for evaluation of recurrent nephrolithiasis.

He has spontaneously passed three stones over the previous 4 years and has recently undergone shockwave lithotripsy twice without success. He has been treated in the past with an unknown medication, but this was discontinued because the parents believed it was of no benefit. Urinalysis demonstrates hexagonal crystals. The likely metabolic diagnosis contributing to this patient's recurrent stone formation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystinuria. Cystinuria is a complex autosomal recessive disorder of amino acid transport involving cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine (COLA). Supersaturation of the urine will occur in patients with the homozygous state. Therefore it is unusual to see a family history with cystine stones, and the age at onset is often in the first or second decade

questions.text: Which of the following classification in biliary injury also includes vascular injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The Hannover classification of bile duct injuries also includes vascular injuries

questions.text: A 24-year-old man had a CT scan  36 hours after a motor vehicle accident. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Main renal artery occlusion.

There is complete absence of enhancement of the entire right kidney, which is caused only by main renal artery occlusion. Segmental occlusion would cause abnormality only in a portion of the right renal nephrogram. Ureteral
injury and UPJ disruption may cause delay in the nephrogram but not complete absence of enhancement

questions.text: A 30 yr old female presented with abdominal pain and lump. USG reavealed a mass arising from liver. CECT shows the following picture. All of the following are true about this malignant tumour  of the liver except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fibrolamellar carcinoma (FLC) is a primary liver cancer that occurs in adolescents and young adults without underlying liver disease These patients do not have a history of cirrhosis or chronic liver disease In the fibrolamellar variant, AFP is raised in only 5% of the patients.

Computed Tomography usually shows a single tumor with well-demarcated margins, with the majority of these tumors showing decreased attenuation. Greater than 70% of the patients demonstrate a calcified central scar.

choices.text: Repeat cystoscopy with random bladder biopsies.
Radical cystectomy because of the patient's young age.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man has gross hematuria and cystoscopy reveals a papillary tumor. Transurethral resection of the tumor reveals a
noninvasive 2-cm papillary low-malignant-potential urothelial tumor. Muscle is present in the resected specimen. All of the
tumor is resected. The best treatment is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Immediate mitomycin C intravesical therapy. PUNLMP is a papillary growth with minimal cytological atypia that is more than seven cells thick and is generally solitary and located on the trigone . PUNLMPis composed of thin papillary stalks where the polarity of thecells is maintained and the nuclei are minimally enlarged.

PUNLMP has a low proliferation rate and is not associated with invasion or metastases. Tumor recurrence is common, and thus perioperative treatment with mitomycin C is warranted.

questions.text: 55-year-old man presents with worsening cirrhosis. After evaluation by a hepatologist, he presents for evaluation for hepatic transplantation. He is informedthat prioritization for transplantation is based on the Model of End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score, and that patientswith higher MELD scores have a greaterbenefit from transplantation. Which of the following contributes to the MELD score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score enables liver allocation to be based on objective variables: total bilirubin, international normalized ratio, and creatinine. The MELD score is a statistical model employed for adult patients that has been shown to have a highpredictive capacity in identifying patients with end-stage liver disease at greatest risk of mortality within 3 months.

choices.text: Observation for now and follow-up in surgery clinic in 6 months
Observation for now and follow-up in surgery clinic if she develops further symptoms

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is seen in a surgery clinic for a bulge in the right groin. She denies pain and is able to make the bulge disappear by lying down and putting steady pressure on the bulge. She has never experienced nausea or vomiting. On examination she has a reducible hernia below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The patient has a bulge identified below the inguinal ligament which is consistent with a femoral hernia. A femoral hernia occurs through the femoral canal bounded superiorly by the iliopubic tract, inferiorly by Cooper ligament, laterally by the femoral vein, and medially by the junction of the iliopubic tract and Cooper ligament. The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high. Therefore, all femoral hernias, even asymptomatic ones, should be repaired. This patient has no evidence of an acute incarceration and does not need emergent repair of her hernia at this time.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is 15 weeks pregnant has new onset of nausea, vomiting, and right-sided abdominal pain. She has been free of nausea since early in her first trimester. The pain has become worse over the past 6 hours. Which of the following is the most common non-obstetric surgical disease of the abdomen during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Appendicitis complicates approximately 1 in 1700 pregnancies at an incidence comparable with that in nonpregnant women matched for age. It is the most prevalent extrauterine indication for laparotomy in pregnancy. The duration of gestation does not influence the severity of the disease, but the diagnosis does become more difficult as the pregnancy progresses. By the twentieth week of gestation, the appendix often lies at the level of the umbilicus and more lateral than usual. Pregnancy should not delay surgery if appendicitis is suspected; appendiceal perforation greatly increases the chance of premature labor and foetal mortality. After appendicitis, biliary tract disease (biliary colic, cholecystitis) is the second most common non-obstetric surgical disease of the abdomen during pregnancy. Pancreatitis, intestinal obstruction, and acute fatty liver of pregnancy are all less common general surgical conditions encountered during pregnancy

questions.text: On colonoscopy a malignant lesion is identified 5 cm proximal to the splenic flexure. There are no contraindications to resection and the decision is made to operate with curative intent. The most appropriate procedure would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This question is simply designed to test candidates' baseline knowledge of common surgical techniques, which are often confused and misunderstood. As with virtually all tumour surgery the aim is to achieve clear resection margins. Therefore the operation is planned tore move the tumour and all mesenteric lymph tissue draining that area. The choice of operation in this case is either an extended right hemicolectomyor left hemicolectomy; left hemicolectomy is associated with the technical difficulty of forming a large bowel to large bowel anastomosis and the preferred technique for tumours located in the transverse colon is therefore an extended right hemicolectomy. This allows a primary anastomosis between the ileum and descending colon, which avoids the end-to-end anastomosis implicit in left hemicolectomy. A right hemicolectomy would not excise the area in question and neither would a sigmoid colectomy or an anterior resection. A total colectomyin this patient would be equally inappropriate, as the removal of the entire colon is not necessary to achieve cure.

choices.text: A normal finding 3 days post laparotomy

questions.text: The nursing staff asks you to review an erect chest radiograph of a 60-year-oldwoman who has undergone open colonic surgery for a pelvic mass 2 days ago.She is comfortable at rest. Her abdomen is distended, with absent bowel sounds.Chest X – ray was done. What is true about the x – ray finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The presence of free air under the diaphragm is not uncommon followingopen and laparoscopic surgery and is the most likely explanationfor this finding. This represents a normal finding 2 days post laparotomy.Other less likely causes of free intraperitoneal air in this settinginclude anastomotic leakage, perforated sigmoid diverticulum and perforatedpeptic ulcer; however, these are extremely unlikely in a patientwho is otherwise well.

choices.text: Right internal jugular approach central line
Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubitalfossae

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is admitted following a stab injury to the right groin. He is bleeding profusely from the wound. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and hispulse is 140 beats/min. He is agitated and mildly confused. His skin is cool andmottled. In this scenario, which is the best mode of fluid delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Optimal fluid volume delivery is through large-bore access achievedwith cannulae inserted into the antecubital fossae. Central linesare generally long conduits with narrow lumens andare therefore less effective at delivering large volumes to hypotensivetrauma patients. The same is true of long lines inserted through a femoralapproach. It may be necessary to perform a long saphenous venouscut-down, but this approach should be reserved for patients whereattempts to obtain standard peripheral venous access have failed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male motorcyclist is brought into the emergency departmentwhere you, as the doctor on call, are asked to assess his consciousness as partof the primary survey. He is unresponsive when you speak to him, but, on rubbinghis sternum, opens his eyes and tries to push your hand away. During yourassessment he also made few sounds that you are unable to understand. HisGlasgow Coma Scale score is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The GCS is a tool used to rapidly assess the consciousness and neurologicalfunction of a patient, particularly (but not exclusively) in thetrauma setting. Thepatient in this scenario will score 9/15 (E2, V2, M5).

questions.text: A 59-year-old males presents with longstanding weight loss, anorexia andlethargy. Physical examination reveals a swelling in the left supraclavicularfossa. A disseminated adenocarcinoma of the stomach is diagnosedfollowing a gastroscopy and computed tomography scan of the thorax and abdomen.This patient has presented with
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Virchow’s node (signal node) is an enlarged, hard, leftsupraclavicular lymph node which can contain metastasis of an intraabdominalmass, e.g. gastric malignancy. Battle’s sign is bruising over the mastoid process following a base of skull fracture involving thepetrous temporal bone. Cloquet’s node refers to the most superior of the deep inguinal lymph nodes, which passes through the femoralcanal. Troisier’s sign is the term given to enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node (Virchow’ snode), usually secondary to advanced metastatic gastric carcinoma. Trousseau’s sign of malignancy is phlebothrombosis of the superficialveins due to cancer induced blood hypercoagulability. Trousseau also gives his name to Trousseau’s sign of latent tetany which may be elicitedin individuals with a low serum calcium level.

choices.text: Screening for pancreatic endocrine neoplasms and hypercalcemia
Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
Total thyroidectomy with frozen section intraoperatively, with modified radical neck dissection reserved for patients with extra-capsular invasion
Right thyroid lobectomy followed by iodine 131 (131I) therapy

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a 6-cm right thyroid mass and palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of one of the lymph nodes demonstrates the presence of thyroid tissue. Which of the following best describes the management of this thyroid disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Treatment of high-risk papillary carcinomas consists of total thyroidectomy. If patients have lymph node metasta- ses in the lateral neck, concomitant modified radical neck dissection should be performed with total thyroidectomy. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid frequently metastasizes to cervical lymph nodes, but distant metastasis is uncommon. Overall, survival at 10 years is greater than 95%. Several scoring systems for determining prognosis have been developed; one of the more common systems takes into account age, grade, extrathy- roidal invasion and metastases, and size (AGES). The surgical management of small papillary thyroid cancers is controversial, as there is a high rate of contralateral disease (thus strengthening the argument for total thyroid- ectomy), although it is unlikely that these small contralateral tumors will ever become clinically significant (thus the argument for lobectomy alone). Medullary, but not papillary, thyroid carcinoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome. Frozen section is not useful in the evalua- tion of thyroid nodules, as extracapsular and vascular invasion is not reli- ably detected on frozen section. Radioactive iodine ablation is used after a total thyroidectomy, not a lobectomy.

choices.text: This dissection can be both Stanford class A and DeBakey type I.
Stanford class A dissections are treated with aggressive medical management of blood pressure.
DeBakey type III dissections are proximal to the left subclavian artery
Stanford class B dissections are always considered surgical emergencies

questions.text: A 60 years old patient presented with acute onset of chest pain radiating to the interscapular region. A CT scan was done. Which of the following statement regarding this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Stanford classification divides aortic dissections into those that involve the ascending aorta and those that do not. Aortic dissections can either be acute or chronic (greater or less than 2-week duration). Acute Stanford class A dissections, representing 60% of all dissections, are considered surgical emergencies. Stanford class B dissections are further divided into complicated (which may require intervention) and uncomplicated (asymptomatic, which can be treated with aggressive medical management) dissections. The DeBakey classification is determined by proximal and distal extent of dissection. Type I involves the ascending and descending aorta, type II only the ascending aorta, and type III only distal to the left subclavian artery takeoff. Therefore Stanford class A dissections include DeBakey type I and II dissections.

questions.text: Match the following Surgical Wound Classification with the hernia repair scenario:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A clean wound is only in contact with the normal skin flora and should have a surgical site infection rate of <2%. An elective inguinal hernia repair is a clean wound. A clean-contaminated wound enters a viscus in a controlled manner; the hernia has a surgical site infection risk of 2%–10%. A contaminated wound has intestinal spillage without active signs of infection and has an infection rate of ∼10% even with antibiotics. Examples of a contaminated wound are ischemic bowel and an unprepped colon. A synthetic mesh can be used with clean and clean-contaminated wounds. Biologic meshes are used for contaminated or dirty wounds if a mesh is needed. Dirty cases are surgeries with active infection such as an empyema and perforated appendicitis.

questions.text: The test done below is done for which surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The picture shows sentinel lymph node dissection using a gamma probe in breast conservative surgery. Evidence from large prospective studies suggests that the combination of intraoperative gamma probe detection of radioactive colloid and intraoperative visualization of blue dye (isosulfan blue dye or methylene blue) is more accurate for identification of SLNs than the use of either agent alone. Some surgeons use preoperative lymphoscintigraphy, although it is not required for identification of the SLNs. On the day before surgery, or the day of surgery, the radioactive colloid is injected either in the breast parenchyma around the primary tumor or prior biopsy site, into the subareolar region, or subdermally in proximity to the primary tumor site. With a 25-gauge needle, 0.5 mCi of 0.2-μm technetium 99m–labeled sulfur colloid is injected for same-day surgery, or a higher dose of 2.5 mCi of technetium-labeled sulfur colloid is administered when the isotope is to be injected on the day before surgery.

choices.text: Surgical excision in a periadventitial plane

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a right-sided slow-growing rounded neck mass located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid. The mass appears to move side to side only. CT of the neck is performed and demonstrates widening of the carotid bifurcation by a well-defined tumor blush. The mass is 3 cm. Optimal management consists of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Widening of the carotid bifurcation by a well-defined tumor blush (lyre sign) on CT is considered a pathognomonic finding for a carotid body tumor. Patients typically present in the fourth or fifth decade with a slow-growing rounded neck mass. It is usually located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid near the angle of the mandible. Carotid body tumors can only be moved side to side but not up or down because of their location within the carotid sheath (Fontaine sign).

Treatment of carotid body tumors is surgical. One dangerous pitfall in excising these tumors is that, in an effort to excise completely, the dissection is carried too close to the artery. In so doing, part of the adventitia of the carotid artery may inadvertently be removed. Since the adventitia is the strongest layer, the artery may weaken and blow out postoperatively. Thus, excision should be done in a periadventitial plane. If a subadventitial plane is inadvertently entered, this increases the risk of hemorrhage and arterial injury. Because of their vascular nature, biopsy is contraindicated.

Routine preoperative embolization is not necessary but should be considered in large tumors (>4cm) (A). Radiation therapy may be considered for long-term tumor control in patients that are not candidates for surgery (e.g., inaccessible site) (B). Chemotherapy has no role in the management of these tumors (C). Excising the carotid bifurcation should be avoided

choices.text: Onset occurs 24 h after a transfusion.
Onset occurs most often after transfusion with freshfrozenplasma.
Clinical findings include dyspnea, hypertension, and bradycardia.

questions.text: A 79-year-old female falls at home. In the ER, she is found to have a pelvic fracture with a large retroperitoneal hematoma. While waiting for angioembolization byInterventional Radiology (IR), the patient becomes hypotensive and is transfused with two units of packed red blood cells and two units of fresh-frozen plasma. After this, the patient starts to complain of shortness of breath, has desaturations, and requires intubation. Which statement best describes a transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The reported incidence of TRALI varies from 1%to 15% of patients receiving transfusions with a mortality rate of5%–10%. It occurs 50 to 100 times more often in critically illpatients. It can occur after transfusion of any component of bloodbut is most associated with fresh-frozen plasma and red blood cells.Several hypotheses exist regarding its pathogenesis, includinghuman leukocyte antigen–specific antibody in the donor directedagainst an antigen in the recipient, resulting in an inflammatoryresponse causing damage to the endothelial lining of the lungs.Criteria for diagnosis include acute onset, usually within 6 h oftransfusion, hypoxemia with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than 300, andbilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray in a patient with no alternativerisk for lung injury. Symptoms include dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, and fever. Treatment is supportive, withapproximately 70%–90% of patients requiring ventilator support.Being diagnosed with TRALI does not affect the ability to receiveblood transfusions in the future. However, risk reduction maneuversincluding restrictive transfusion policies and washing of storedblood products should be employed with future transfusions.

questions.text: Identify the knot shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aberdeen Knot.

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: continuous loop from a single continuous suture is known as Aberdeen Knot.

questions.text: A patient of thyroid nodule, euthyroid status,  underwent hemithyroidectomy. The histopathological image of the specimen is shown in the figure. This picture is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The pathologic characteristics of papillary thyroid carcinoma include nuclear grooves and inclusions. Psammoma bodies are also pathognomonic of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Papillary thyroid carcinoma spreads via the lymphatics, while follicular thyroid carcinoma spreads hematogenously. MTC spreads via the lymphatics initially. Amyloid deposits represent collections of calcitonin within the thyroid specimen. Hürthle cell carcinoma is a subtype of follicular thyroid carcinoma that has a more aggressive phenotype.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with complaints of mouth pain while chewing and night sweats. She has had many past episodes of sialolithiasis in her parotid gland, but they often resolve spontaneously after a few days of sucking on lemon drops. Physical examination reveals a swollen right parotid gland which is later confirmed to be a pleomorphic adenoma. She undergoes a parotidectomy. Shortly after the proce- dure, she complains of numbness over her right earlobe. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sialolithiasis (salivary ductal stones) can increase the risk of developing a tumor of the gland. Lemon drops will stimulate saliva production and help facilitate passage of the stone. Pleomorphic adenoma is benign and considered the most common neo- plasm of the parotid gland. In general, the risk of nerve injury is greatest in patients with reoperation of the neck (e.g., incomplete parotidectomy requiring re-excision). Total parotidectomy or excision involving the deep lobe of the parotid glands leads to a higher rate of cranial neuropathy, compared to superficial parotidectomy. In most cases, the neuropathy is transient and improves within a month. The most common nerve injured during parotidectomy is the facial nerve, most commonly the marginal mandibular branch, and will present with facial droop (A). However, other nerves are also at risk. The greater auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2–C3) and provides cutaneous sensation to the lower portion of the ear, including the earlobe. Injury to the trigeminal nerve can cause widespread numbness in the face (C). How- ever, this type of injury occurs rarely because of the deep location, immediate branch- ing, and redundancy of these nerves. An injured spinal accessory nerve will present with partial paralysis of the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles (D). The auricu- lar branch of the vagus nerve provides cutaneous sensation to the ear canal, not the earlobe

questions.text: A patient of portal hypertension, with history of variceal bleed 3 times, portal hypertension is refractory to medical management underwent the surgery shown in figure. Identify this shunt surgery done for portal hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is proximal splenorenal shunt which is also known as Linton’s shunt. This is a type of non selective shunt in which splenectomy is done.

questions.text: An 85-year-old nursing home patient is found to have a worsening stage III sacral pressure ulcer. The ulcer is debrided and tissue for culture obtained. Tissue cultures reveal 10*8 organisms per gram of tissue after operative debridement. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of the patient’s wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel hasrecommended a staging system for pressure sores that is useful inplanning treatment. Stage I is represented by the presence of nonblanching erythema of intact skin. Stage II is characterized bypartial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis or dermis. Clinically,the ulcer is manifested as a blister, abrasion, or shallow crater.Stage III is full-thickness skin loss with involvement of theunderlying subcutaneous tissue. Stage III wounds may extenddown to but not through the underlying fascia. Stage IV representsfull-thickness skin loss with extensive destruction or tissue necrosisof underlying structures, which may include muscle and bone.Studies have shown that wounds with quantitative cultures revealingmore than 10*6 organisms per gram of tissue that undergo reconstructionwith skin or even muscle flaps have a significantly greaterrisk for complications, including infection, accumulation of fluid,and wound dehiscence. Similarly, a skin graft is unlikely to survivein an environment with such a high bacterial inoculate.

questions.text: You are asked to see a 24-year-old male with no medical problems who sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh 1h prior to arrival. He is afebrile with an HR of 136 beats/minand a BP of 90/60 mmHg. He is initially alert and asking forwater but becomes confused during your brief interview. He is in which class of hemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent ERCP reveals the congenital cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The patient has congenital cystic dilations of the extrahepatic biliary ducts. Nonsurgical treatment of these cysts
results in high morbidity and mortality, and therefore surgery is advised in all cases. The present recommendation is for complete resection of the cyst with cholecystectomy and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Since malignant changes in choledochal cysts have been frequently described, complete resection rather than the performance of a drainage procedure is preferred whenever the resection can be done safely. Liver transplantation offers a potential cure for patients with intrahepatic cystic dilation (Caroli disease).

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is being worked up for an elective cholecystectomy. She doesn’t have any complains apart from right hypochondrial pain. She has undergone a LSCS 2 years back without any complications.  General physical examination is within normal limits. Her coagulation profile shows Prothrombin time of 15 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 56 seconds, platelet count of 188000/cu.mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anti-phospholipid antibodies. Asymptomatic patient having elevated aPTT especially female of reproductive age group female is suggestive of antiphospholipid antibodies. In APLA the aPTT is elevated since antibodies are against phospholipids which are a part of aPTT reagent, thus inhibiting coagulation invitro.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has noted cramping abdominal pain for the past year associated with fever, easy fatigue, and low-volume diarrhoea. On physical examination, there is right lower quadrant tenderness. Bowel sounds are present. His stool is positive for occult blood. A colonoscopy reveals mucosal edema and ulceration in the terminal ileum, but the transverse and descending portions of the colon are not affected. Peripheral blood examination shows large oval RBC with hyper segmented neutrophils. Laboratory studies show serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies. An ileal biopsy is likely to show.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Non caseating granulomas. The patient is having Crohn disease (patchy involvement of bowel, ileal involvement, and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies) which shoes granulomas

questions.text: A 22-year-old known case of Marfan syndrome has been detected a diastolic murmur in the aortic region which of the following is a likely complication of the cardiac manifestation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The clinical findings are suggestive of an aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur in aortic area in a Marfan, regurgitant lesions lead to eccentric hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed of Rheumatic fever and was planned to start with penicillin injections. A test dose was given in antecubital fossa after which there was redness and swelling in the area withing 15 minutes. Which of the following cell is most likely leading to such a manifestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mast cell. It is early phase of type I hypersensitivity which is mediated by mast cell (Histamine).

questions.text: A child is having multiple petechiae and purpura on the skin, abdominal cramps for last 3 days. He had a bout of respiratory tract infection prior to onset of these symptoms. Now the patient presents to you with reduced urine output for last 24 hours and pedal edema. urine examination shows many RBC and RBC casts. IF shows IgA deposits along the endothelium. A renal biopsy is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The image shows a crescentic glomerulonephritis and in a child after respiratory tract infection it is suggestive of HSP. IF showing IgA along endothelium is also suggestive of HSP.

questions.text: An 8-month-old male infant is admitted to the hospital because of a bacterial respiratory infection. The infant responds to appropriate anti- biotic therapy but is readmitted several weeks later because of severe otitis media. Over the next several months, the infant is admitted to the hospital multiple times for recurrent bacterial infections. Workup reveals extremely low serum antibody levels. The infant has no previous history of viral or fungal infections. The most likely diagnosis for this infant is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient is having a primary immunodeficiency disorder based on the history. Reduced serum antibody levels indicate it is a Bruton’s Agammaglobulinemia. IgA deficiency should have only reduced IgA not all immunoglobulins.

questions.text: Worst prognostic histological type of breast carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ductal. Although medullary carcinoma has pleomorphic cells the prognosis is better. Ductal has a poor prognosis. Another type called inflammatory carcinoma in which a ductal carcinoma blocks the lymphatics leading edema and redness in the overlying skin (hence the name) has poor prognosis because they are usually stage III or IV at the time of diagnosis.

questions.text: Most consistent histological finding in COVID lung is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Diffuse alveolar damage. In COVID there is ARDS happening in lung which will show Diffuse alveolar damage which is most characteristic. Even Endothelitis can be seen but most characteristic is DAD. Inflammation is very scant in COVID lung

questions.text: A medical student is describing histology of an anaplastic carcinoma of thyroid, which of the following histological feature is not applicable for features of anaplasia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capsular Invasion. Anaplasia which means lack of differentiation is a characterised by options B, C D, and loss of nuclear polarity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has presented with headache not relieved by NSAIDs for last few weeks now she is having diminished vision. Her Hb is 18g/dl, RBC count 7.5 million AND HEMATOCRIT IS 52%. Physical examination revealed 6th and 8th nerve palsy. Fundoscopy revealed bilateral papilledema and increased in retinal vessels which are dilated tortuous. Imaging of brain shows a tumor in the cerebellum. Which mutation is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

VHL. The patient is having a retinal angioma by description on fundoscopy and a cerebellar tumor (? hemangioblastoma) in addition patient is having polycythaemia suggests that the patient is having an inherited cancer syndrome suggestive of a Von Hippel Lindau syndrome. Option A is associated with Schwannoma and meningioma. Option C is neurofibromas and Neurofibrosarcomas, option D is seen in Gorlin Syndrome and is associate with medulloblastoma and basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bleeding per rectum. Colonoscopy shows a polyp and excision was done. Histological examination is as shown below. Which of the following is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hamartomatous polyp. Underneath the epithelium presence of smooth muscle admixed with glands indicates that there is disorganisation of normal structures in the tissue which is Hamartoma. And such polyp is hamartomatous polyp seen in Peutz jaghers syndrome.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma with intracranial metastasis
Squamous cell carcinoma with a paraneoplastic manifestation
Small cell carcinoma with intracranial metastasis
Small cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestations

questions.text: A 56-year-old smoker had cough, past 3 weeks although he has completely stopped smoking since then. He has vomiting, fatigue, weigh loss of 6 kg. he acts confused and is not oriented to place and time. A blood examination shows serum sodium 115mEq/L, calcium levels are normal. Chest CT shows a small lesion in the wall of the peri hilar bronchus and a few perihilar lymph nodes. Histology is as shown in the image. Which of the following is correct explanation of this patient’s manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Small cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestations. The patient is having hyponatremia which is a frequent paraneoplastic syndrome manifestation in small cell carcinoma due to SIADH.

questions.text: An eight-year-old child is having repeated diarrhoea. Blood examination shows Dimorphic anemia. The child’s daily diet consists of meat, fruits, green leafy vegetables, and roti (wheat bread). Biopsy from duodenum is as shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely cause of the peripheral blood finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Folic acid and iron deficiency. The patient is having a flattening of villi on duodenal biopsy suggests there is an enteropathy affecting upper intestine (possibly Celiac). Iron and folic acid are absorbed from upper intestine (B12 is absorbed from ileum so upper intestinal enteropathy do not cause such deficiency.

questions.text: A 78-year-old had abdominal aneurysm rupture, which was surgically repaired he was transfused 3 units of packed RBC and 1 unit of FFP. During next unit of blood transfusion, the patient develops breathlessness, O2 saturation is 86%, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate 28/min, BP 120/80. Auscultation reveals bilateral crepitations, a clinical diagnosis of pulmonary edema secondary to blood transfusion was made. The patient is given inhalational oxygen and bronchodilators. Which of the following additional treatment is required in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

None of the above.  The patient is having TRALI, breathlessness with depleting O2 saturation and Normal BP which requires inhalational oxygen and bronchodilators nothing more. Steroids won’t help because TRALI occurs due to anti HLA antibodies from the donor.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with unilateral proptosis. Imaging shows mass behind the eye near the optic nerve. Histological examination is as shown in the image. the tumor is negative for Desmin, S-100 but positive for GFAP. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Glioma. The tumor is negative for Desmin (not Rhabdomyosarcoma) and negative for S100 (not Schwannoma) option D shows Small round cells with rosette (not seen in the image). the tumor cells are GFAP (Glial fibrillary acidic protein) positive suggestive of a Glioma (optic nerve glioma is a pilocytic astrocytoma which shows pink fibres known as Rosenthal fibres as sheen in the image
